msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth 1768-1849 71477273 62567029
to Mrs. Strickland, Trim Vicarage, June 6th. 1827

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in a manuscript. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
You have made an impression upon
me - You have shaken me and the Kildare
Street - The facts you state are certainly
very strong - But hear the other side -
- I read some of the statements in
your letter to Mr. Butler, who is no
partisan of the Kildare Street Society
but who warned me that there is
something which perhaps you do not
know to be said to account for there
having conducted themselves in the
manner they did respecting the money
promised for the schools which were
built on their plans -

The parish priest of Graigue
(wherever that may be I do not know)
but it is in Dr. Doyle's diocese) recd a
considerable sum of money from the
Kildare St. Socy. for building a school
to be on the Kildare St. plan - But as soon
as it was built & that he had recd the
money he withdrew from all connexion connection
with the Socy. & upon?

To prevent the recurrence of similar
treatment the Kildare St. then?
de-
termined determined to require the security of
the leases which you mention

Observe that I do not think that
this story of the priest of Gracgore?even
granting it be in all points true will
serve as a complete justification of the
Kildare St. socy's conduct though it may
be pleaded in extenuation - I am
ready to anticipate what I am sure
you will say, - and justly - that one
person's having broken the terms of
his agreement with them is no reason
that they should not fulfil their agree-
-ments agreements with those who adhered to
their terms & whom they had no
cause to suspect would break faith
with them -

What they should have done wd
have been to publish the transaction
- The disgrace would have been sufficient
punishment to the individual, or indeed
I think they might have taken the law of him
for breach of contract - But undoubtedly
they should have fulfilled their own
contracts - They might afterwards have
demanded any security they thought
necessary for future bargains & might
have stated their reasons - then they wd
have been in the right - now I think
they are in the wrong - But not so much
as they appeared to me to be when
I had heard only your side of the story

You see my dearest Mrs. Strickland
That I write quite frankly to you which
I think is the only way to write or to
deal – Far from being bored by your
letter , I was penetrated with your kind
ness kindness & proud to feel that you set such
value on my opinion - The value of
sincerity it assuredly has -

I cannot tell you how sorry I am to miss
seeing Mr. Strickland - I was obliged to
leave home before his arrival - How
much I should have enjoyed hearing him
open his London budget! - But you can
not have every thing - I am with Harriet Butler &
to day & going to Aunt Ruxton tomorrow &
this is good enough - I must be content
with missing Mr. Strickland & having
an inflamed eye lid - an eye lid so much in-
flamed & with such an evisisalatous
disposition in the cheek beneath as warns
me to obey Harriets injunction "Write
no more Maria - Write no more!
div.closer:
I am dear Mrs. Strickland
sincerely & affectionately
Yours
Maria Edgeworth

postscript.p:
Harriet Butler
sends love to you
- She is a happy wife
& Mr. Butler a most happy
husband
Thank you again & again for your most
entertaining account of Mr. Strickland in
London - more entertaining than Horace in London
